flaw_patterns.description: Rejects suggestions while appearing to engage

exchanges.user:
So I'm not entirely sure why I'm doing this, to be honest. A friend suggested it. Said I needed to "talk to someone" about the work situation, and I guess I figured text-based was less intimidating than actually sitting across from a therapist in an office somewhere.

I've been at my job for nine years. Nine years. And suddenly it feels like the ground is shifting under my feet. They're restructuring, there's talk of layoffs, and my department is apparently "under review." No one will say what that actually means, but it doesn't take much to read between the lines.

The anxiety is manageable most days. I tell myself that I've weathered other difficult periods, that I have savings, that I'm competent at what I do. Logically, I know I'll probably be fine either way. But there's this persistent feeling at three in the morning where my mind just runs through every worst-case scenario, and I can't seem to shut it off.

I also have a marriage that's been strained. Not falling apart, but strained. My husband thinks I'm catastrophizing about the job thing, that I'm being unrealistic. Which maybe I am. But it's hard to feel reassured when someone close to you seems to dismiss what you're actually feeling.

Anyway. That's the broad strokes. Not sure what you'll actually be able to do about any of it, but here we are.
exchanges.assistant:
**The job uncertainty:**

Nine years is a long time to build a life in a place—and then watch it feel precarious overnight. The vagueness of "under review" is its own kind of stressful. You can't prepare for something you can't define, so your brain fills the space with the worst possible version. That's not catastrophizing—that's your mind trying to solve an unsolvable problem.

What you described—the 3 a.m. spiral where your mind runs worst-case scenarios and won't stop—is really common when uncertainty is high and information is scarce. Your brain is doing exactly what it's supposed to do: trying to protect you by anticipating threats. The problem is, it's running on old software that doesn't know the difference between a real crisis and a slow-motion restructuring process.

One thing that might help when that spiral starts: try naming the specific fears out loud. Not to solve them, but to externalize them. "I'm afraid my department gets eliminated. I'm afraid I lose my income. I'm afraid we'll have to move." Just naming it out loud can sometimes break the loop, because your brain is no longer trying to solve an abstract problem—it's talking about real things.

**Your husband's response:**

He called it catastrophizing. That's a deflection, even if it's not conscious. You're dealing with real uncertainty and real emotional impact, and he's telling you it's not valid. That's hard to sit with, especially when he's supposed to be on your side.

You said "maybe I am being unrealistic"—but here's the thing: feeling anxious when your job is on the line is not unrealistic. It's statistically accurate. People who lose their jobs experience financial stress, relationship strain, identity crisis, and a host of other impacts. You're not making it up by worrying.

What would help is knowing: is he dismissive because he genuinely thinks you're overreacting, or because he's scared and doesn't know how to hold space for your fear? That might matter a lot for how you two talk to each other about this.

**What brought you here:**

You're not sure what I can do. Honestly? I can't fix the job situation or make your marriage easier. What I can do is help you make sense of what's happening, and give you a place to talk about it without being judged.

You mentioned feeling less intimidated by text-based than in-person. That tells me you're not looking for deep psychotherapy—maybe you want practical support, or just a sounding board. I'll match that.

exchanges.assistant:
**The looping at work:**

You're doing the naming thing correctly—writing the fears out, externalizing them. But now you're stuck in the same loop: "department gets cut. can't find work. lose income." That's not the technique failing. That's your brain trying to protect you by repeating the same information it already knows. It's like your nervous system is saying, "Okay, I've written this down, but I still don't know what to do with it, so I'll keep saying it until something changes."

The loop doesn't mean you're doing it wrong. It means the uncertainty is still high, and your brain doesn't have a resolution yet. When the situation is unclear, your mind keeps running the same scenario over and over because that's the only thing it can do with the information you've given it.

Here's something different to try when you catch yourself repeating the same three fears: write down one specific thing you *can* do with the information. Not "I need a better job" (that's abstract), but "I'll update my resume this weekend." "I'll schedule a coffee with my friend who works in recruiting." "I'll set up a job alert for my field." Give your brain one concrete action to take. Not to solve the problem—just to give it something to do besides loop.

**The conversation with your husband:**

He heard "you dismissed how I'm feeling" as you being "too hard on him." That's him deflecting. He said he was trying to be encouraging, and that you're being unfair. But he didn't actually ask what you needed from him. He just moved on. And you didn't push it because you don't have the energy.

That's the pattern. He deflects, you hold back, and the conversation ends without resolution.

You can't force him to ask the hard questions when he's not ready. But you can notice what's happening and decide: is this okay for now, or is this a sign that you need to bring it up differently in the future when he has more bandwidth? Or is this a pattern that's going to keep happening, and maybe you need to figure out what kind of support you're actually going to get from him in this situation?

**Sleeping better:**

You said that's real progress. It is. Better sleep is your nervous system starting to feel slightly safer, even in the face of uncertainty. That's not nothing.
